document.docAuthor: Garraffoni, André R. S. & Melchior, Marina P.
document.docTitle: New species and new records of freshwater Heterolepidoderma (Gastrotricha: Chaetonotidae) from Brazil with an identification key to the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and new records of freshwater Heterolepidoderma (Gastrotricha: Chaetonotidae) from Brazil with an identification key to the genus

docTitle.emphasis:
New species and new records of freshwater
Heterolepidoderma
(Gastrotricha: Chaetonotidae ) from Brazil with an identification key to the genus

subSection.paragraph: ANDRÉ R. S. GARRAFFONI & MARINA P. MELCHIOR

paragraph.emphasis: Laboratório de Evolução de Organismos Meiofaunais, Departamento de Biologia Animal, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Caixa Postal 6109, 13083- 970 , Campinas, São Paulo, Brazil .

subSection.paragraph:
A new species of freshwater
Heterolepidoderma
(Gastrotricha) was found in Brazil .
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
is unique in possessing a three-lobed head, three types of dorsal keeled scales, a thin band of cilia on the head, connecting the two bands of ventral cilia, and an interciliary area with elliptical keeled scales with short spines.
Heterolepidoderma famaillense
Grosso & Drahg, 1991
is reported for the first time outside the type locality in Argentina , and we make some initial remarks on
H . aff. majus
Remane, 1927
, a possible undescribed species. A dichotomous key for all freshwater species of
Heterolepidoderma
, with distributional data, is also provided.

Key words:
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
, Chaetonotida , systematics, biodiversity, meiofauna, Neotropical region

In the present study, we describe a new freshwater species of
Heterolepidoderma
found during a meiofaunal survey in the State of São Paulo, Brazil . We also report
Heterolepidoderma famaillensis
for the first time outside Argentina and provide new data using light microscopy with differential interference contrast (DIC) and scanning

1 .
Balsamo et al. ( 2009 )
listed 21 freshwater
Heterolepidoderma
species, two of which (
H . fallax
and
H . loripes
) were considered species inquirenda ,
Kånneby ( 2011 )
described two new species, and Kånneby et al. ( 2012 ) described additional one new species.

electron microscopy (SEM). Remarks on
Heterolepidoderma aff. majus
, a possibly undescribed species, and a comparison with
H . majus
, found in Brazilian inland waters by
Kisielewski ( 1991 )
, are also made. Finally, we present a dichotomous key for all known freshwater species of
Heterolepidoderma
.

Before this study, the known freshwater fauna of
Heterolepidoderma
of Brazil was composed of one endemic species (
H. jureiense
Kisielewski 1991
) and three widespread species (
H. gracile
Remane 1927
,
H. majus
Remane 1927
and
H. ocellatum
Metschnikoff, 1865
) (
Kisielewski 1991
). With the description of
H . mariae
sp. nov.
, the number of known freshwater gastrotrichs in Brazil now stands at 57 species.

Samples of the upper sediment layer were collected with a manual corer from four distinct stations in the East Atlantic hydrographic basin, Minas Gerais State, Brazil : Preto River, city of São Gonçalo do Rio Preto (sandy/ muddy/rocky substrate):
18 °08' 13 ''S
–
43 ° 20 ' 13 ''W
(
Fig. 1
); Soberbo Stream (sandy/rocky substrate):
18 ° 11 ' 40 ''S
–
43 ° 34 '00''W
(
Fig. 1
); Água Limpa Stream, city of Diamantina (sandy/rocky substrate):
18 ° 12 ' 53 ''S
–
43 ° 37 '02''W
(
Fig. 1
;
Fig. 2
A); unnamed stream in Sempre-Vivas Federal Park, city of Diamantina (sandy/rocky substrate):
17 ° 47 ’S
–
43 ° 38 ’W
(
Fig. 1
;
Fig. 2
B); one station in the Southeast Atlantic hydrographic basin, Minas Gerais State, Brazil : unnamed stream on Itambé Mountain, city of Santo Antônio do Itambé (sandy substrate):
18 º 23 ' 51 ''S
–
43 º 19 ' 44 ''W
(
Fig. 1
); and two stations in the Paraná hydrographic basin, São Paulo State, Brazil : floating vegetation with
Eichhornia
sp. in an urban lagoon, city of Paulínia:
22 ° 47 ' 38 ''S
–
47 °08' 44 ''W
(
Fig. 1
;
Fig. 2
C–D); Broa Dam, city of São Carlos (sandy substrate):
22 ° 11 ' 21 ''S
–
47 ° 52 ' 56 ''W
(
Fig. 1
).

subSection.paragraph:
a. http://www.faunaitalia.it/checklist/invertebrates/families/ Chaetonotidae .html-accessed
09/ 10 / 2015
b. According to Fauana Europaea (
Balsamo et al. 2015
)

* original description; **as
Heterolepidoderma ocellatum Metschnikoff
f. sphagnophilum Gastrotrichs were located by sorting small amounts of sediment poured into Petri dishes under a Zeiss Stemi 2000 stereomicroscope. The animals were isolated alive and mounted individually on glass slides, anaesthetized with 2 % MgCl 2 and digitally documented under a Zeiss Axio Imager M 2 light microscope equipped with DIC and an AxioCam MRC 5 digital video camera. For SEM analysis, some specimens were fixed in 2 % glutaraldehyde in cacodylate buffer or 2 % paraformaldehyde in PBS, then rinsed in 0.1 M PBS, dehydrated in a graded ethanol series, treated with HMDS (hexamethyldisilazane) (
Hochberg & Litvaitis 2000
), mounted on aluminum stubs, and sputter-coated with gold-palladium. Observations were carried out under a JSM 5800 LV SEM at the University of Campinas (UNICAMP).

Records of species of
Heterolepidoderma
were obtained from the literature (
Tab. 1
). Geographic coordinates were obtained using Google Earth® (Google 2015 ) and the distribution maps were prepared using the DIVA-GIS 7.5 software (
Hijmans et al. 2012
).

heading.emphasis:
Family
Chaetonotidae
Gosse, 1864
( sensu
Leasi & Todaro, 2008
)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype . Photographs of one specimen (adult), collected from an urban lagoon on
26 /Jun/ 2015
, in floating vegetation with
Eichhornia
sp. in the city of Paulínia, Brazil , available at the Museum of Zoology, University of Campinas, Brazil , under accession number ZUEC GCH 19 . Paratypes . Photographs of five specimens (adults), collected from an urban lagoon on
03/Mar/ 2015
, in floating vegetation with
Eichhornia
sp. in the city of Paulínia, Brazil , available at the Museum of Zoology, University of Campinas, Brazil , under accession numbers ZUEC GCH 20, 21, 22, 23, 24 and 25 .
Additional material. Three specimens were examined alive with a compound microscope and are no longer extant (collected at Broa Dam, city of São Carlos, Brazil ); two specimens were prepared for SEM.

Etymology. The specific epithet honors Dr. Maria Balsamo, who has greatly contributed to our understanding of freshwater gastrotrichs. She was also very kind and helpful to the first author ( ARSG ) when he first started studying this tiny, funny-looking worms 7 years ago.

Autapomorphies. Dorsal body surface covered by keeled scales of three different shapes, on the head a thin line of cilia connecting the two lomgitudinal bands of ventral cilia, interciliary area with elliptical keeled scales with short spines, with pharyngeal field portion naked.

Diagnosis. Small species, 129–151 Μm in total length. Body width 9–11 Μm, 19–25 Μm, 27–31 Μm, 16–17 Μm and 11–14 Μm at head, neck, trunk, base of furca and adhesive tubes, respectively. Three-lobed head with developed cephalion, pleurae and hypostomium. Anterior sensory bristles anchored by papillae and posterior sensory bristles anchored by double-keeled scales. Straight furca with rather thin adhesive tubes pointing slightly outward at distal end. Dorsal body surface covered by keeled scales of three different shapes, distributed into 20– 22 longitudinal rows of 34–38 scales each. Columns converge on the narrow parts of the body. Ventral interciliary area with round keeled scales, pharyngeal field portion naked, and one pair of large keeled scales. Ventral ciliation in two longitudinal bands, connected in the anterior part of the body. Subterminal mouth. Pharynx 35–38 Μm in length, with anterior and posterior swellings.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. Morphometrical features of
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
X = mean; N=number of specimens measured.

tr.th: Total number of longitudinal rows of scales
Number of scales in a single longitudinal row

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Schematic drawings of
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
A) Dorsal view. B) Ventral view. The scales are not in scale. Scale bars: 25 Μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Description based on holotype .
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
is a small-sized species, 138 Μm in total body length (
Figs 2–4
). Head is three-lobed, epipleurae more developed than hypopleurae. Cephalion 9 Μm in width. Hypostomium 9.5 Μm in width, well developed without anterior teeth, upper part straight, lower part concave (
Figs. 4
E; 5 B; 6 A–B). One pair of cephalic ciliary tufts with two different sizes of cilia: 8, 15 Μm, respectively. Ocellar granules absent.

Body width 22 Μm at the head (U 10 ), 20 Μm at the neck (U 25 ), 29 Μm at the trunk (U 54 ) and 13 Μm at the base of the furca (U 80 ). Head slightly delimited from trunk by neck constriction that gradually widens into the trunk, which reaches its greatest width around U 45–50 . The trunk then tapers into a straight furca, 7 Μm in length, with rather thin adhesive tubes, 13.5 Μm in length, pointing slightly outward at their distal ends. Base of furca covered dorsolaterally, laterally and ventrally with keeled scales. Anterior and posterior sensory bristles present, anterior pair at U 26–27 anchored by papillae and posterior pair at U 84 anchored by double-keeled scales.

Dorsal body surface covered by 20–22 longitudinal rows of 34–38 keeled scales with visible edges (
Figs. 3
A; 4 B; 5 A; 6 C–F). The median row of dorsal scales is straight, except in the narrowest part of the neck and the rearmost trunk region, where it is replaced by 4 to 6 rows of diagonally arranged scales. Three different dorsal scale shapes: a) head scales small, oval with trilobate keels, 2.3–2.5 Μm in length and 1.4–2.1 Μm in width (
Figs. 3
A; 4 B; 5 A; 6 C); b) trunk scales elongate-oval with slight constriction in the median region, straight posterior end and trilobate keels, 4–6 Μm in length and 1.5–2 Μm in width (
Figs. 3
A; 4 B; 5 A; 6 D–E); c) posterior body scales elongate-oval with fine keels drawing out into simple fine spines, 5 Μm in length and 2 Μm in width (
Figs. 3
A; 6 D,F).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
holotype. DIC photomicrographs: A) Habitus. B) Dorsal view of distribution and shape of scales. C) Ventral view showing the paired keeled scales at the base of the furca. D) Ventral view showing the interciliary scales. E) Ventral view showing the connection between the parallel rows of cilia. Scale bars: 22 Μm.

FIGURE 5.
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
paratype. DIC photomicrographs: A) Dorsal view of distribution and shape of scales. B) Ventral view of distribution and shape of scales and cilia. White arrow indicates hypostomium. Scale bars: 22 Μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The interciliary area is covered by 5–6 longitudinal rows of 14 elliptical keeled scales with short spines ( 1– 1.5 Μm), in each longitudinal row, with pharyngeal field portion naked. The last posterior row (including ventral terminal scales) consists of four larger keeled scales, with two different sizes (approximately 2,5 and 5 Μm in length). Ventral ciliation appears as two longitudinal bands that merge on the head, forming a transverse band of cilia (
Figs. 3
B; 4 C–D; 5 B; 6 A,B).
Mouth subterminal, 4–6.4 Μm in diameter; pharynx 35–38 Μm in length with anterior and posterior swellings. Anterior region of pharynx without cuticular rods.
Some specimens were in parthenogenetic phase, with the egg ( 60–67 Μm in length) positioned laterally in the trunk region.

Remarks. The genus
Heterolepidoderma
includes 22 species that inhabit inland water. Among them, only
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
,
H. majus , H. brevitubulatum
Kisielewski, 1981
and
H. jureiense
have a clearly three-lobed head.
H. jureiense
can be excluded from further comparison as it is the only species with ventrolateral lamellae among these four species.
Heterolepidoderma brevitubulatum
has adhesive tubes extremely short and slightly bifurcate, whereas in
H. mariae
sp. nov.
and
H. majus
, the adhesive tubes are at least 4 times longer and not bifurcate.
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from
H. majus
because it has a dorsal body surface covered by keeled scales with three different shapes, as well as a transverse band of cilia on the head connecting the two bands of longitudinal ventral cilia, whereas
H. majus
has only one type of keeled scales on its dorsal surface, and its two ventral bands of cilia separate.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Heterolepidoderma mariae
sp. nov.
SEM photomicrographs: A) Ventrolateral view of anterior end of the trunk. B) Ventrolateral view of anterior end of the trunk. White arrow indicates the connection between the parallel rows of cilia. C) Close-up of dorsal region of anterior end of the trunk, showing the keeled scales. D) Dorsal view of distribution and shape of scales. E) Close-up of dorsal region of the trunk, showing the keeled scales. F) Close-up of dorsal region of posterior end, showing the keeled scales. Scale bars: A, B, 5 Μm; C, 4 Μm; D, 10 Μm; E, F, 2Μm.

bibRefCitation.author: Grosso
bibRefCitation.refString: Grosso, L. E. & Drahg, F. (1991) Gastrotricos dulceacuicolas de la provincia de Tucuman IV. Acta Zoologica Lilloana, 40, 47 - 51.

subSubSection.paragraph: Localities. Brazil : cities of Diamantina, São Gonçalo do Rio Preto and Santo Antônio do Itambé, state of Minas Gerais. Reported for the first time in Brazil .

Material. Photographs of four specimens (adults), collected on
29 /May/ 2009
in the city of Diamantina, Brazil , available at the Museum of Zoology, University of Campinas, Brazil , under accession numbers ZUEC GCH 13, 14, 15 and 16 . Six specimens were examined alive with a compound microscope and are no longer extant.

Elongated body (
Fig. 8
A). Five-lobed head with two pairs of cephalic cilia. Ocellar granules absent. Dorsal scales overlapping; longitudinal rows of keeled scales parallel to the body (
Fig. 7
B–C; 8 B). Ventral ciliation as a continuous field of transverse rows covering the entire ventral body surface in the pharyngeal and beginning of the intestinal regions, splitting at the beginning of the intestinal region (U 26–27 ) to form two separate longitudinal bands (
Fig. 8
C). The interciliary area is covered by elliptical keeled scales, with the pharyngeal portion of the field naked (
Fig. 8
C). Ventral terminal scales consists of one pair of larger elliptical keeled scales in the rearmost portion of the ventral region (
Fig. 7
D). Subterminal mouth (
Fig. 7
A). Pharynx with posterior swellings only.

Remarks. The Brazilian specimens exhibit similar ranges to those of Argentinean specimens (
Tab. 3
), but we were able to find specimens both smaller and larger than those reported by
Grosso & Drahg ( 1991 )
. In terms of morphology, the specimens in our study agree with the original description of
H. famaillense
previously reported in Argentina , Tucuman, Famaillá ( 27 °03′ 16 ″S– 65 ° 24 ′07″W), particularly in the pattern of ventral cilia, and in the distribution and shape of the dorsal keeled scales.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 3. Morphometrical features of
Heterolepidoderma famaillense
. X = mean; N= number of specimens measured.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Heterolepidoderma famaillense
. DIC photomicrographs: A) Lateral view of head and neck region. B) Ventral view showing the paired keeled scales at the base of the furca. C) Lateral view of trunk region, showing the distribution and shape of scales (white arrow). D) Lateral view of trunk region, showing the distribution and shape of scales. White arrow indicates dorsal keeled scales and black arrow indicates ventral small interciliary scales. Scale bars: 14 Μm.

FIGURE 8.
Heterolepidoderma famaillense
. SEM photomicrographs: A) Habitus in lateral view. B) Close-up of lateral region of the trunk, showing the keeled scales. C) Ventrolateral view of head and neck, showing the ciliation and shape of scales. Scale bars: A, 20 Μm; B, 2 Μm; C, 10 Μm.

FIGURE 9.
Heterolepidoderma aff. majus
. A) Dorsal view of head and neck region. B) Dorsal view of head and neck region, showing the distribution and shape of scales. C) Ventral view showing the cilia and interciliary scales. Scale bars: 25 Μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Localities. Brazil : city of São Carlos, state of São Paulo.

Material. Photographs of two specimens (adults), collected on
13 /Jun/ 2015
in the city of São Carlos, Brazil , available at the Museum of Zoology, University of Campinas, Brazil , under accession numbers ZUEC GCH 17 and 18 .

Remarks. As reported above, within the genus
Heterolepidoderma
, only
H . mariae
sp. nov.
,
H. majus , H. brevitubulatum
and
H. jureiense
have clearly three-lobed heads. The specimens collected in Broa Dam do not exhibit three different shapes of dorsal scales (like
H . mariae
sp. nov.
), or extremely short and slightly bifurcate adhesive tubes (like
H. brevitubulatum
), or ventrolateral lamellae (like
H. jureiense
). Although we collected sediments at the same site where
Kisielewski ( 1991 )
found
Heterolepidoderma majus
, we noticed considerable differences in our two specimens tentatively identified as
H. majus
. We were not able to clearly observe the keels transforming into short spines that project beyond the edges of posterior scales (
Fig. 8
); the morphometrical features of our specimens are different from those reported by
Kisielewski ( 1991 )
(
Tab. 4
), and the interciliary area of the pharyngeal and beginning of the intestinal regions clearly have small keeled scales. However, a description of a putative new taxon is beyond the scope of the present study because few specimens were studied and more material is needed for a complete description.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Morphometrical features of
Heterolepidoderma aff. majus
. X = mean; N= number of specimens measured.

subSubSection.paragraph:
*present study; **
Kisielewski ( 1991 )
- specimen from São Carlos region, state of São Paulo.

subSection.paragraph:
This survey has given the description of one new species of
Heterolepidoderma
(
H . mariae
sp. nov.
), extended the known geographic range of
H. famaillense
, and reported
H. aff. majus
24 years after the genus was first reported in Broa Dam (
Kisielewski 1991
).

The freshwater fauna of
Heterolepidoderma
of Brazil is composed of both endemic and widespread species, since
H . mariae
sp. nov.
and
H. jureiense
were found only in Brazil and H.
famaillense
is found only in Argentina and Brazil (Neotropical biogeographic region), whereas
H. gracile
,
H. majus
and
H. ocellatum
were found in North America , Europe and Asia (Neotropical, Nearctic and Palearctic biogeographic regions). The freshwater fauna of
Heterolepidoderma
of the world shows a similar pattern, as most of the described species have an endemic or narrow range of distribution and only a few species are widespread
H. dimentmani
Kisielewski, 1999
,
H. jureiense
,
H. longicaudatum
Kisielewski, 1979
,
H. mariae
sp. nov.
,
H. multiseriatum
Balsamo, 1978
,
H. obesum
d'Hondt, 1967
,
H. obliquum
Saito, 1937
,
H. patella
Schwank, 1990
,
H. tenuisquamatum
Kisielewski, 1981
and
H. trapezoidum
Kånneby 2011
are known only from their respective type localities;
H. acidophilum Kånneby et al.

2012 ,
H. famaillense
Grosso & Drahg 1991
,
H. joermungandri
Kånneby 2011
,
H . kossinense (
Preobrajenskaja, 1926
)
,
H . lamellatum
Balsamo & Fregni, 1995
,
H . macrops
Kisielewski, 1981
,
H . pineisquamatum Balsamo, 1981
have been reported at two or more localities, but within the same biogeographic region;
H . brevitubulatum
Kisielewski, 1981
and
H . majus
are known to occur in two distinct biogeographic regions; and
H . gracile
and
H . ocellatum
have been reported in three distinct biogeographic regions (
Figs. 10–13
). It is interesting to note that three of the four widespread species (
H . majus
,
H . gracile
and
H . ocellatum
) were described in the late 18 th or early 19 th centuries, which means that taxonomic problems may arise due to incomplete descriptions, lack of referable collected materials and/or absence of photos using light microscopy with DIC, or using SEM.

Heterolepidoderma majus

.

subSection.paragraph:
Heterolepidoderma
is undoubtedly a genus of systematic and biogeographic interest, being one of few gastrotrich genera that include both marine and freshwater species. Thus, future studies could focus on constructing a phylogenetic hypothesis for the genus and increasing the number of DNA sequences deposited in databases, to shed light on three important questions. First, Kånneby et al. ( 2013 ) concluded that
Heterolepidoderma
is not monophyletic, based on nuclear and mithocondrial genes from seven distinct species of the genus (
H . loricatum Schrom, 1972
,
H . macrops
,
H . ocellatum
,
H . acidophilum
, and three species not formally described) and other Chaetonotida species. Thus, from a taxonomic standpoint, where does
Heterolepidoderma
truly stand? Second, are all types of “keeled scales” that are observed on
Heterolepidoderma
and other freshwater gastrotrichs—e.g., certain
Aspidiophorus , Ichthudium
and
Chaetonotus
—homologous? Third, are
H . majus
,
H . gracile
and
H . ocellatum
cryptic species, or is their morphological variation underestimated? Kånneby et al. ( 2012 ) described the new species
H . acidophilum
based on morphological and molecular data, but this species was previously considered a variation of
H . ocellatum
, under the name
H . ocellatum
var. sphagnophilum
Kisielewski, 1981
.

Schwank ( 1990 )
provided taxonomic keys for the freshwater species of
Heterolepidoderma
, but seven additional new taxa have been described since his publication (
Grosso & Drahg 1991
;
Kisielewski 1991
;
Balsamo & Fregni 1995
;
Kånneby 2011
; Kånneby et al. 2012 ; present study) and two species have been considered species inquirenda (
Balsamo et al. 2009
), summing up to a total of 22 valid species. A revised key therefore seems appropriate.

heading.emphasis:
Key to Freshwater Species of the Genus
Heterolepidoderma

sp. nov.

- Absence of transverse band of cilia on the head connecting the two bands of longitudinal ventral cilia; longitudinal rows of dorsal scales parallel to the body axis....................................................

Remane, 1927

Remane, 1927

H. longicaudatum
Kisielewski, 1979
- Furca base covered with scales; adhesive tubes more or less straight pointing slightly outward at their distal ends.......... 8

8 . Oval scales in 35–40 longitudinal rows; Ventral ciliation as a two separate longitudinal bands for the whole body.................................................................................
H. kossinense
Preobrajenskaja, 1926

- Elliptical scales in 30–32 longitudinal rows; Ventral ciliation as a continuous field of transverse rows covering the entire ven- tral body surface in the pharyngeal and beginning of the intestinal regions, splitting at the beginning of the intestinal region to form two separate longitudinal bands........................................
H. famaillense
Grosso & Drahg, 1991
9 . Presence of cuticular reinforcements (or rods) in the anterior part of the pharynx................................... 10
- Absence of cuticular reinforcements (or rods) in the anterior part of the pharynx................................... 13

10 . Two pairs of cuticular reinforcements (or rods) in pharynx.......................... ..
H. dimentmani
Kisielewski, 1999
- One pair of cuticular reinforcements (or rods) in pharynx..................................................... 11

11 . Paired ventrolateral row of delicate lamellae absent.................................
H . joermungandri
Kånneby, 2011
- Paired ventrolateral row of delicate lamellae present......................................................... 12

12 . Interciliary area in pharyngeal and anterior part of intestinal portions naked, 35 longitudinal rows of scales...........................................................................................
H. jureiense
Kisielewski, 1991

- Entire interciliary area covered with small keeled scales with spiny processes, 17–23 longitudinal rows of scales................................................................................
H. lamellatum
Balsamo & Fregni, 1995
13 . Longitudinal rows of dorsal scales more or less curved....................................................... 14
- Longitudinal rows of dorsal scales straight, parallel to the longitudinal axis...................................... 17

14 . Pharynx swellings only at the posterior end (large terminal bulb); 40–45 longitudinal rows of dorsal scales..........................................................................................
H. multiseriatum
Balsamo, 1978
- Pharynx cylindrical or with swellings at both ends; 10–25 longitudinal rows of dorsal scales.......................... 15

16 . Crescent-shaped scales present; ocellar granules absent.....................................
H. obliquum
Saito, 1937

- Crescent-shaped scales absent; ocellar granules present.................................
H. macrops
Kisielewski, 1981

17 . Presence of keeled scales with a band of simple spines on dorsal trunk...............
H. acidophilum Kånneby et al. 2012
- Absence of keeled scales with a band of simple spines on dorsal trunk........................................... 18

18 . Scales unkeeled (minute spine-like point distally), oblong to triangular; presence of a pair of round scales on the ventral side of the furca base..........................................................
H. pineisquamatum
Balsamo, 1980
- Scales keeled; absence of a pair of round scales on the ventral side of the furca base................................ 19

19 . Scales visible; oblong-elliptical keeled scales, which taper distally to short simple spine ( 8–9 µm).................................................................................................
H. ocellatum
Metschnikoff, 1865
- Scales minute; keels very delicate and hardly visible ( 1–2.5 µm)............................................... 20

20 . Pharynx swelling only at the posterior end (large terminal bulb); extremely wide trunk...........
H. obesum
d'Hondt, 1967
- Pharynx swellings at both ends; neck constriction gradually widens into the trunk.................................. 21

21 . One pair of ocellar granules; furca base without scales...........................
H. tenuisquamatum
Kisielewski, 1981

- No ocellar granules; furca base covered with scales....................................
H. illinoisense
Robbins, 1965

subSection.paragraph: This work was supported by grants from the Conselho de Pesquisa e Desenvolvimento—CNPq ( 478825 / 2013 - 7 ) and the Fundo de Apoio ao Ensino, à Pesquisa e Extensão—Unicamp ( 2031 - 15 ). We are thankful to both Anete P. Lourenço and Thiago Q. Araújo for sharing the photos of Biribiri State Park and Sempre-Vivas Federal Park and for comments on the first draft of this manuscript, and to Axell Minowa for his assistance with the scale drawings. Tobias Kånneby and an anonymous referee are also acknowledged for offering suggestions that greatly improved the paper.
